column4: greetings. i've tried installing ubuntu (feisty fawn) before, but was unsuccessful for some reason. the install aborted, but the partition was left there. then i installed ubuntu again, and it all worked well. that's what i'm using now. i just got the message informing me that the partition disk space is 100% used. i'm wondering how i can delete the other partition with semi-working ubuntu that i do not (nor intend to) use.
you could boot up the live cd and use gparted to erase it.
could i do it without loading it up? does ubuntu not have a partition manager that i can access at this stage?
that would let you format it as an extra partition for storing music on or something.
actually yes- you'd have to unmount the partition first, but if you're not using it, thats fine.
initially, i created a partition for ubuntu from windows. then ubuntu divided it further.
i don't think it's mounted currently. could you tell me how to erase it?
i'd rather completely erase it, in comparison to just deleting files from it.
yeah sure - hit alt-f2, and type "gparted".
Could not open location 'file:///gparted'
!gparted
there you go.
did you see the bot message?
thanks, ubotu
yeah, sorry. got dinner. :P doing the stuff now
After unpacking 6316kB of additional disk space will be used.
i'm unsure if i have that much.
cool.
*checks*
6mbs?
if only i knew how to check :S
the message told me that 100% of the disk is used.
